title: Time Series Gene Expression Data Classification via L1-norm Temporal SVM

author: Carlotta Orsenigo, Department of Management, Economics and Industrial Engineering, Politecnico di Milano

segmentation: OK, thank you, good afternoon to everybody.
I'm going to present them catterson ego.
I'm going to present a joint work with Carlo virtually so we are both from Politecnico di Milano.

During my talk I'm going to deal with the problem of time series classification, in particular, gene expression profiles classification and I will briefly introduce the concept of dynamic time warping and I will provide the formulation of the L1 norm support vector machines that I'm going to present.
Our temporal variant of L1 norm, a support vector machines which makes use of the notion of dynamic time warping in order to perform a time series gene expression classification.
And finally, I will describe some computational results on two benchmark data.
Sets which is the main motivation of these work.

This paper was motivated by the great number of experiments dealing with the collection and analysis of gene expression Time series as they evolve overtime and the resulting datasets cool for the development of new classification methods which are able to take into account also the temporal Dimension Time series gene expression classification plays a prominent role in several domains, for instance in.
Functional genomics studies.
The automatic classification of genes based on their temper evolution in the cell cycle may be helpful for assessing the function of a gene.
Since genes exhibiting similar expression profiles are supposed to be functionally related.
As another example, we may consider the prediction of their responses to drag a of a set of passions.
In this case, the passions may exhibit different rates of disease development and in this particular case.

The overall expression profiles of two patients may be similar but not aligned since individuals may progress at different speed in general, Time series classification is a supervised learning problem which is aimed at leveling univariate or multivariate temporal sequences.
Several approaches have been proposed for solving this problem and the most common one is represented by two stage procedure in which first rectangular representation of the set.
Of temporal sequences is derived, and then a traditional classification method is applied.
Another approach which has been used in the context of univariate time series labeling is based on the notion of a dynamic time warping.
What is dynamic time warping time?

Warping distance is a measure of similarity which has been originally introduced in the context of a signal processing and speech recognition and has been successfully applied as a proximity measure for clustering or labeling univariate or bivariate temporal sequences as a similarity measure, the warping distance is proving to be even more robust and versatile with respect to their kleidion distance since.

It is able to cope with sequences of variable length and the second reason is that it is able to automatically perform shift in the sequences in order to detect similar profiles which are characterized by different phases.

The warping distance between a pair of time series can be efficiently computed by means of our dynamic optimization algorithm, and for this reason this distance is often called the dynamic time warping.
I just want to go briefly into details of dynamic time warping distance, the warping distance between two times here is is defined as the length of the shortest warping path in a directed graph.

In this graph, each node represents the alignment of the corresponding periods of the two time series whose similarity we want to compute, and each node in this graph can be connected as at most three outgoing arcs.
Since it can be connected to its.

Artisan nodes on the vertical axis or on there is ontel axis or along the diagonal and the length of each are connecting two nodes is represented by the squared distance associated to the potential alignment of the corresponding periods of the two time series.

Now in this graph, a warping path is any path connecting the source vertex VF to the destination vertex of yellow and the warping distance is defined as the length of the shortest warping path in this graph.

For computational reasons, very often, in order to compute the warping distance between two terms, here is some sorts of local or global constraints are set in order to prevent the alignment of periods which are set too far from each other.
OK, we imagine to have a set of temporal sequences which have to be classified in order to perform time series classification.
We may resort to traditional support vector machines.

In SQM, we know that we have to solve the quadratic optimization problem in which the objective function is given by the sum of two terms, the classification error, the second term into the objective function and the first term in which represents which is related to the generalization capability of the model.
This quadratic formulation has several advantages, among which probably the most prominent one is the possibility of applying kernel functions in order to derive a new linear separation.

However, other norms have been considered in order to express the margin maximization, and in particular eloir normal inner formulations of SRAM have recently attracted much attention, since they can benefit from the high efficiency of the solution.
Procedure is existing for linear optimization problems.
L1 norm as support vector machines have proven to be even more effective than their quadratic counterparts in the presence of many features an in the presence of many noise and accessory features.

The main contribution of our paper is to extend L1 norm support vector machines in order to improve the discrimination capability for solving Time series classification problems and to do so I have to introduce a new family of binary variable speed.
Where each binary variable pizza by indicates whether the corresponding example that is a time series in our case, is misclassified by the optimal separating hyperplane hyperplane.
Not here is the model we are going to propose in order to perform time series classification.
This model has been called the L1 norm temporal support vector machines and is based on a mixer, Internet or mixed integer optimization problem.
The objective function in this model is composed by the sum of three terms.
The second term is the classification error as in traditional support vector machines.
The first term is the linearized version of the L1 norm of the vector W. Which is expressed in terms of the continuous bounding variables.
You thanks to the presence of these family of constraints into the model.
The last term is the main novel contribution of this paper is represented by the sum of the warping distances between all pairs of time series which are assigned to the same class.
This term depends on the value, sorry.

This terms depends on the values of the warping distance between two time series and depends also on the value of a farther continuous variable are which says whether the two temporal sequences line the same half space with respect to the optimal separating hyperplane.

It is possible to show that the value of this variable is properly set by the presence of these two families of constraints into the model which are in their turn defined about the previous misclassification binary variables.
Defining the previous slide.
This is a mixed integer optimization problem.
This problem includes this term.

This term is the sum of the warping distance between all pairs of time series assigned to the same class and the rationale behind these inclusion was that we suppose that M series exhibiting the same expression profiles belong also to the same class.
Solving the new model for evaluating for identifying a sub optimal solution to this model, we propose an approximate procedure.
These solution algorithm is based on a sequence of linear optimization problem.
The first problem is represented by the linear relaxation of the previous model and each problem in the sequence is obtained by fixing to zero the binary variable with the smallest fractional value.
In the optimal solution of its predecessor, and this is a very fast approximate procedure which can be used in order to find a suboptimal solution of the previous formulation.
Mixed integer formulation.
Further details of this solution procedure can be found in.
Paper some Commission computational experiments have been performed on two benchmark datasets, and these are the two datasets.
So the first one of these datasets contain.
We completed the complete characterization of the M RNA transcript levels of the yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae.

Particular gene expression Time series were collected on 70 time points with an interval regular interval of 10 minutes between a pair of a single pair of measurements and the second data set in stratum has been called Ms data set and contains a gene expression.
Profiles of patients suffering from multiple sclerosis.
These passions are good responder or poor responder to recommend human interferon beta.
The second data set is a binary completes to a binary classification problem.
The first data set instead leads that one multicategory classification problem.

Since time series gene expression profiles are supposed to be assigned to are known to be assigned to five different phases, which actually represent the class labels in our setting, the second data set instead is composed by several gene expression profiles.
Since several measurements have been performed at several time points, the first time points he is before the 1st stock ministration of the Triangle.
Then after three months and after six months during the first and the second year of the therapy.
Five methods have been considered for comparison with our temporal extension.
The first one is traditional L1 norm support vector machines.

Then we have considered support vector machines with radial basis and dynamic time warping as kernels, and then we have considered the key nearest neighbor classifier based respectively on the Euclidean distance an on the dynamic time warping distance.
In particular, this last method has proven to be very effective for the classification of unimatic.
Anybody to temporal sequences?
Our accuracy measure was represented by the accuracy that is at the rate of corrector classification.
We use five times so far for cross validation for accuracy evaluation and on each training set we apply 3 for cross validation.
For parameters, tuning for each data for each classification algorithm.
This table contains all the parameters values we have tested for measuring the tuning phase.
In order to ensure a fair comparison, we assured to use the same fold in each of the cross validation iteration.
This table contains the average accuracy.
Prefer obtain and, by the alternative, competing techniques on all the data sets.
The multiple sclerosis datasets are instead 6 datasets, since for each time points from 2:00 to 7:00, we extracted the corresponding time series profiles in order to obtain 60 friend datasets.
From these table, some empirical conclusions can be drawn from the comparison between L1 norm tempura support vector machines and L1 norm support vector machines.

We may not just that our temporal variant was able to outperform Elba Norma support vector machines in terms of accuracy, with an increase in accuracy ranging within this interval, and in general, our proposed variant was able to achieve the highest rate of correct predictions on all datasets on these data set and almost multiple sclerosis datasets, in particular on these six datasets.

Also, the use of warping distance appeared promising when the dynamic time warping is used as the kernel function with SVM, we may notice that the average classification accuracy provided by all methods on these datasets decreased when more.
Therefore, gene expression profiles were considered for each patients.
This is probably due to the presence of missing profiles in the last measurements.
However, even in this case the temporal extension we proposal was able to exhibit.

A milder degradation of its classification performance is compared to most of the other competing techniques for what concerns the Easter data set, we may say that our temporal extension and support vector machines based on dynamic time warping kernels provided comparable results.
However, in the even in this case, our method was able to achieve the highest rate of correct predictions.
Conclusions and future works.
We have proposed a new supervised method for solving a time series classification problem.

This method is made based on a mixed integer optimization formulation which represents an extension of L1 norm, a support vector machines and which makes use of the time warping distance in order to include a measure of similarity into the classification problem.
Experiments performed on two benchmark datasets showed the effectiveness of the proposed approach.
Future extensions will be pursued along three main directions.
We are going to test the novel technique of a wider range of time series datasets.
We are interested in investigating other time series similarity measure to be included into the formulation into the support vector machines model and to study alternative.
You restrict procedure for solving the resulting mixed integer optimization problem.
We are going to formulate.
Thank you to everybody here on summer papers.
You may refer to.
More or less the details of what I have presented here today.
